title: Picking the Fastest Database to Store Time-Series Data | by Sergey Makhnist | Medium
text:
# Picking the Fastest Database to Store Time-Series Data

Sergey Makhnist
4 min read¬∑Aug 31, 2025
--
Listen
Share
It started with a simple question:
If I take raw market tick data and try to build 5-minute OHLCV bars ‚Äî a calculation that every trading desk, quant researcher, and charting engine performs thousands of times a day ‚Äî which database will give me the answer the fastest?
I wasn‚Äôt looking for marketing claims or synthetic benchmarks. I wanted an
apples-to-apples, real-world test
of the databases that practitioners actually reach for when dealing with time-series workloads. In finance, milliseconds can mean the difference between capturing alpha and watching it slip away. So I set out to measure, not theorize.

## Contenders

- PostgreSQL(row-store, tuned indexes)
- TimescaleDB(PostgreSQL extension with hypertables/chunks)
- ClickHouse(general-purpose columnar OLAP)
- KDB+(time-series powerhouse used in HFT)
- QuestDB(SQL-first time-series database)
Note: Anyone attentive will notice that
InfluxDB
isn‚Äôt included. The reason is that, while it‚Äôs positioned as a time-series database, InfluxData frames it more as a ‚Äúmetrics and events‚Äù platform (observability, IoT). It‚Äôs not a natural fit for large-scale financial tick history, so I excluded it to focus on engines commonly used for market data analytics.

## Benchmark task

Task
:
Compute 5-minute OHLCV time series from raw tick data spanning 3 trading days
, representative of charting/analytics pipelines and intraday quantitative research.
Dataset size
: 100 million tick records (0.1 billion) distributed across three symbols (
MSFT, GOOG, AAPL
), with about 1 million ticks per symbol per day over 100 trading days in total.
Note: The task is intentionally defined to compute OHLCV bars over multiple days to exercise potential partitioning effects in the underlying database. Since many systems leverage date-based partitioning, distributing the workload across 3 days helps validate performance across multiple partitions rather than a single contiguous one.

## Results


```
Title       | Runs (3 attempts, ms)   | Avg (ms)------------+-------------------------+---------PostgreSQL  | 3,735 / 3,252 / 3,492   | 3,493TimescaleDB |   967 / 1,126 / 971     | 1,021ClickHouse  |   535 / 556 / 549       |   547KDB+        |   104 / 112 / 111       |   109QuestDB     |    24 / 23 / 29         |    25
```

All the scripts used for these tests are open-sourced and available on my GitHub:
https://github.com/smakhnist/timeseries-db-comparison
Speed-of-QuestDB vs others (lower is better):
- vsKDB+: ~4.4√ófaster (109 ‚Üí 25 ms)
- vsClickHouse: ~22√ófaster (547 ‚Üí 25 ms)
- vsTimescaleDB: ~41√ófaster (1,021 ‚Üí 25 ms)
- vsPostgreSQL: ~140√ófaster (3,493 ‚Üí 25 ms)

## What the numbers say (and don‚Äôt)


### PostgreSQL (5th / Last place)

Last place, as expected for a row-store under analytical scans and aggregations ‚Äî even with a sensible composite index.
Note: For PostgreSQL, the schema includes an index on
(symbol, timestamp)
to ensure
O(log n)
lookups, as you‚Äôd reasonably do in production.

### TimescaleDB (4h place)

Roughly
4√ó faster than PostgreSQL
, thanks to hypertables, chunking, and time-aware planning. Still far behind column stores for this read pattern ‚Äî consistent with its
PostgreSQL heritage
.

### ClickHouse (3rd place)

Around
2√ó faster than TimescaleDB
. As a
columnar OLAP
database, it shines on wide scans, aggregations, and compressible numeric time-series. The result aligns with expectations for column stores on read-heavy analytics.

### KDB+ (2nd place)

About
5√ó faster than ClickHouse
in this test. KDB+ is renowned for vectorized, in-memory analytics over time-ordered data and extremely efficient time-window operations ‚Äî hence its long-standing dominance in HFT/quant environments.
Note:
In our KDB+ benchmark runs we did
not preload any data into memory
. Query execution directly triggered reads from the corresponding date partitions. This distinction is important, as preloading data into memory can significantly change performance characteristics.

### üèÜ QuestDB (1st place)

The surprise winner
here, ~
4.4√ó faster than KDB+
on this specific OHLCV query. This underscores how far this TSDB has come for SQL-driven, time-bucketed analytics.

## Important caveats (read this before you crown a winner)

A blazing-fast
read
benchmark is not the whole story. Before choosing a database for market data at scale, consider:
- Ingestion throughput & concurrencyEspeciallymulti-threaded writesat millions of rows/second, back-pressure behavior, and tail latency under load.
- Compression & storage efficiencyColumnar engines often deliver excellent compression on numeric telemetry/ticks, but ratios vary by engine, encoding, and schema design. Storage footprint directly impactscostandI/O.
- Query concurrency & fairnessWhat happens when dozens of analysts and services hit the cluster at once?
- Operational maturityTooling, observability, backup/restore, version upgrades, cluster elasticity, failover, and ecosystem integrations matter ‚Äîa lot.
- Feature set fitJoins, out-of-order ingestion, window functions, etc.
Put differently:
QuestDB outperformed in my read test
, but that
does not
automatically make it the best production choice for your constraints.

## Where each database can fit

- Large enterprises / latency-sensitive, mission-criticalKDB+remains a strong candidate due to itsmaturity, predictable low-latency behavior, and long track record in demanding financial shops ‚Äî despite its cost and learning curve.
- Medium-size firms / quant research / fast time-to-valueQuestDBis compelling as a starting point thanks to itsoutstanding query performancehere and agentler learning curve.
- Broad analytical ecosystems / mixed workloadsClickHousecontinues to be an excellent general-purpose analytical store ‚Äî great compression, strong SQL, and proven scale ‚Äî often a pragmatic backbone for market-data analytics.
- PostgreSQL/TimescaleDBIdeal when you needrelational featuresand already live in the Postgres ecosystem; better suited foraggregated barsand metadata than forraw tick firehoses.

## The bigger thesis

For years, KDB+ was the de facto answer for high-end tick analytics. The landscape is shifting:
QuestDB has now demonstrated it can beat KDB+ on certain read-heavy workloads.
That doesn‚Äôt erase KDB+‚Äôs strengths (deterministic low latency, maturity, deep ops knowledge in the industry), but it shows that a credible alternative now exists.

## What‚Äôs next

This article focuses on
query performance
. In the
next piece
, I‚Äôll compare
ingestion throughput
(single-threaded and multi-threaded), examine
compression ratios
, providing a balanced view of both read and write performance.
Code Samples
All the benchmarks and examples discussed in this article are available in my GitHub repository:
https://github.com/smakhnist/timeseries-db-comparison
Feel free to explore, run the tests, and adapt them to your own use cases.
